S2.T1.caption: Table 1. Existing multi-objective federated learning works.
S2.T1.table:
Work Objective Scope Specific Objectives Type of Algorithm
(Ju etÂ al., 2023; Cui etÂ al., 2021; Mehrabi etÂ al., 2022; Yin etÂ al., 2022) Worst-case Fairness, Utility Gradient-based
(Zhu and Jin, 2020; Zhong etÂ al., 2022; Morell etÂ al., 2022; Chai etÂ al., 04; Yin etÂ al., 2022) Average-case Efficiency, Fairness, Robustness, Utility Gradient-free
references: In a multi-objective federated learning problem (MOFL), participants aim to optimize multiple competing objectives (e.g., privacy leakage, utility loss, learning cost, and fairness). MOFL typically leverages multi-objective optimization approaches to find Pareto solutions for these objectives. Existing research on MOFL mainly has two lines of direction. Table 1 summarizes these works.

FL setting and Treat Model. We focus on horizontal federated learning (HFL), which involves Kğ¾K participating parties that each holds a private dataset Dk,kâˆˆ[K]subscriptğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾D_{k},k\in[K]. The server is semi-honest, and it may launch privacy attacks on exchanged information to infer participantsâ€™ private data. To mitigate privacy leakage, each participant applies a protection mechanism to the model information that will be shared with the server.
Table 2 summarizes frequently used notations in this paper.

references: The MLP consists of 2 hidden layers and a softmax layer. Each hidden layer has 256 neurons, and the softmax layer has 10 neurons. The modified LeNet consists of 2 convolutional layers, 2 hidden layers, and a softmax layer. Each convolutional layer has 32 channels and a kernel size of 5Ã—5555\times 5, each hidden layer has 128 neurons, and the last softmax layer has 10 neurons. All activation functions are ReLU. Table 3 summarizes the structures of the two models.

references:
We use three experimental settings to investigate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithms: (1) use Randomization (RD) to protect data privacy and minimize utility loss and privacy leakage; (2) use BatchCrypt (BC) to protect data privacy and minimize utility loss and training cost; (3) use Sparsification (SF) to protect data privacy and minimize utility loss, privacy leakage, and training cost.
Table 4 summarizes the three experimental settings and following elaborates on the setup of each setting.
